title-group.article-title: Wave motions in non-uniform one-dimensional waveguides

contrib-group.aff: Department of Engineering Mechanics, Shijiazhuang Tiedao University, China

author-notes.corresp: Shuqi Guo, Department of Engineering Mechanics, Shijiazhuang Tiedao University, North-second East Road 17, Shijiazhuang 050043, China Email: shuqig@yahoo.com.cn

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2011 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Wave approach is used in the analysis of wave motions in one-dimensional non-uniform waveguides. Under assumptions of constant wave velocity and no wave conversion, one class of non-uniform rods including four different profiles results. The obtained results indicate kinetic energy is preserved as constant and wave amplitude is inversely proportional to square root of the cross-section area of the rod. The obtained spectrograms and dispersion relations indicate that under certain conditions there exists a cut-off frequency, below which waves do not propagate along the non-uniform waveguides. The conclusions are similar for high frequency longitudinal wave motions of arbitrary non-uniform rods. For a Euler-Bernoulli beam with exponent variation in geometry and material variation, the bending wave motion is also analyzed including its cut-off frequencies.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Non-uniform elements and materials are frequently encountered in engineering, such as cone rods, rotor blades, equal strength beams, sword-like or tower-like structures, and functional graded materials. It is important to study its dynamic characters, such as wave propagation and free vibration. Waves can propagate freely without reflection and conversion in a certain class of non-uniform one-dimensional waveguides even the properties of the waveguide vary rapidly. In these cases, the wave amplitude changes as a function of position but the power associated with wave is preserved along the waveguide as in uniform waveguides (Langley, 1999). Of special concern in this paper are non-uniform waveguides with variation in geometric and material properties.

There is a class of non-uniform waveguides, where wave reflection and conversion do not occur, such as the shapes of acoustic horns including conical, exponential, sinusoidal, and catenoidal curves. The results for non-uniform acoustic waveguides can be equally applied to structural waveguides with the same variation undergoing longitudinal and torsional motion, because their governing equation has the same mathematical form (Lee et al., 2007).

In this paper, the propagation of longitudinal and bending waves in non-uniform structures with variations in geometric and material properties is studied through theoretical analysis. The analysis shows that non-uniform structures, under certain conditions, do generate a cut-off frequency, below which waves do not propagate along the structure. Hence, the considered rods and beams are capable of filtering out low frequency and they behave as high-pass mechanical filters. The filtering capabilities of the considered class of rods are investigated for different types of profiles.

The present paper consists of five sections. In section 2, longitudinal waves with the assumptions of constant wave velocity and no wave conversion are investigated, which leads to a class of non-uniform rods including four profiles. The corresponding free vibrations are studied in section 4. In section 3, longitudinal wave propagation in non-uniform rods with arbitrary variable cross-section is analyzed. In section 5, the bending wave motion is analyzed for a Euler-Bernoulli beam with exponent variation in geometry and material variation.

sec.title: 2. Longitudinal waves in a class of non-uniform rods
sec.p: In this section, the wave approach is used in the analysis of the longitudinal wave motion in non-uniform rods, where the wave velocity is assumed to be constant and no wave conversion occurs. This condition results in one class of non-uniform rods with square, exponential, square of hyperbolic cosine or square of cosine variation in cross-section area, which are shown as equations (12), (13), (16) and (18) respectively.
Consider the waveguide in a non-uniform rod undergoing longitudinal motion. The displacement u(x, t) is governed by (1)

If the material modulus E and mass density ρ of the rod are assumed to be constant while the cross-sectional area A(x) varies in axial direction shown as Figure 1, the governing equation (1) is transformed as (2) where f(x) = A′/A and c0 2=E/ρ. The prime stands for differentiation with respect to x. Figure 1.
Section of a non-uniform waveguide.

If the cross-sectional area A(x) is assumed to be constant while the material properties E and ρ vary as (3) the rod is the class of axial functional graded material, whose governing equation is the same as equation (2), and f(x)=p′/p, c0 2=E0/ρ0.
Assume the traveling wave solution of equation (2) is the form of (4) where a(x) is the wave amplitude. Substitution of it into governing equation (2) yields two equations as (5) (6)

Substitution of f(x)=dA(x)/dxA(x) into equation (5) and solving the equation, one could find its solution as (7) where a0 and A0 are the amplitude and the cross-sectional area of the rod at x = 0, respectively.

Eliminating a from equations (5) and (6) yields (8) (9) where b is introduced as a parameter. Apparently, when b > 0 and ω<ωc=c0b, the wave number k is negative, so waves cannot propagate along the rods; this frequency ωc is called the cut-off frequency, which is calculated and tabulated in Table 1. In order to solve equation (9), four cases are discussed. (i) Table 1.

In this case, the solution of equation (9) is read as (10) where c is a constant. In terms of f(x)=dA(x)/dxA(x), equation (10) is rewritten as (11) and its solution is (12)
The corresponding free vibrations of square variation expressed by equation (12) have been investigated by Abrate (1995) with a functional transformation method. (ii)
In this case, f(x)=±2b. and substitution of f(x)=dA(x)/dxA(x) into the equation, its solution of A(x) is (13) where b = c2/4. If c = 0, then the cross-section area A(x) is constant. (iii)
In this case, the solution of (9) is (14)
Substitution of f(x)=dA(x)/dxA(x) into equation (14) yields (15)
And its solution is (16) where b = c2.
In this case, the solution of (9) is
Substitution of f(x)=dA(x)/dxA(x) into it yields (17)

And its solution is (18) where b = −c2. The corresponding free vibrations of square of cosine variation expressed by equation (18) have been investigated by Kumar and Sujth (1997) with a functional transformation method. Substitution of equation (7) into equation (4) yields the traveling solution (19) where k has a unified expression shown as equation (22). Carefully observing the value of parameter b and the expressions of cross-section area A(x) in equations (12), (13), (16) and 18), one finds (20)
Then substitution of equation (20) into ωc=c0b yields a unified solution for cut-off frequency, (21)

In fact, solving ordinary differential equation (21) will yield the obtained four solutions of A(x) in this section once more. Substitution of equation (20) into equation (8) yields frequency-wavenumber relation (22)

With the help of equation (22), it is easy to obtain the phase velocity as (23) which implies that phase velocity is great than c0 for the rods with exponent and square of hyperbolic cosine variation in cross-section areas. Differentiating the two sides of equation (22) with respect to k yields k=ωdωdk1c0 2, i.e (24) where cg is group velocity. Then one finds that group velocity is inversely proportional to phase velocity. In terms of equations (22), (23) and (24), the ω − K Spectrogram, dispersion curves of phase velocity and group velocity are plotted in Figures 2, 3 and 4 respectively. In these three figures, solid lines, dash lines, dash-dot lines, and dot lines are the curves for square of hyperbolic cosine, exponent, square and square of cosine variation in the cross-section area respectively. The corresponding parameters are E = 2.1 × 1011Pa, ρ = 7.8 × 103kg/m3, c0=E/ρ=5188.7 m/s, c=0.5. Figure 2.

In term of the traveling solution, its kinetic energy in one unit length of the rod could be easily obtained as T=12ρA(x)|∂u∂t|2=12ρa02A0ω2, which indicates that the kinetic energy is preserved as a constant value. However, the stain energy V of the traveling wave in one unit length is not constant. It is
Then the wave energy in one unit length is the sum of kinetic energy and strain energy (25)

The characters of these wave motions are calculated and presented in Table 1 in detail, such as wave amplitude, wave number, wave velocity, wave energy and the value of parameter b. Here the value of b is constant. However, this value is no longer a constant for the rods with arbitrary variable cross-sections, which is discussed in the next section.

sec.title: 3. Longitudinal waves in non- uniform rods with arbitrary variable cross-sections
sec.p: As for the non-uniform rod with arbitrary variable cross-sections, consider its harmonic motion u(x, t) = U(x)eiωt, governing equation (1) could be transformed as (26) where λ=ωc0. Let V(x)=A(x)U(x), equation (26) is transformed to equation (27) or equation (28) (27) where q(x)=d2A(x)dx21A(x).

sec.title: 3.1. Asymptotic properties of high-frequency longitudinal wave
sec.p: If the right hand side of equation (28) is treated as known function, its solution is (29) where k=ω2c0 2-q(0), i.e. (30)
Due to (31)

Because U(x)=1A(x)V(x) and q(x) is finite, equation (31) is transformed as (32) where c1 and c2 is relative to boundary conditions. Then, if ω is large enough, a rod with arbitrary variable cross-section A(x), one finds the form of the solution the same as equation (19). If the wave arrives at an arbitrary position of the rod, the wave motion at this position could be seen as a wave source. In this case, the wave number in equation (30) is rewritten as (33) which implies that characters of the wave motion are functions of positionx. These characters include the wave number k, the cut-off frequency, the ω − K spectrogram, dispersion relation of phase velocity and group velocity.

sec.title: 3.2. More accurate analysis of the high-frequency longitudinal wave
sec.p: In this subsection, the form of positive going traveling solutions in equation (4) is assumed as (34)

Then, the solutions of equations (26) and (27) could be assumed as (35) (36) where Λ(x)=a(x)A(x) and (37) which implies the wave source is at x = 0. Substitution of equation (36) into equation (27) yields two equations as (38) (39)
The solution of equation (38) is (40)
In terms of Λ(x)=a(x)A(x), the wave amplitude is obtained as (41)
Substitution of equation (39) into equation (38) yields (42)
However, due to its nonlinearity, it is difficult to obtain its solution. If the first term of the left side of equation (42) is neglected, one could find an approximate solution of h′(x), i.e. (43)
Equation (37) implies that the wave source is at x = 0, so (44)
If the wave source is at x = x0, then (45) (46)

Substitution of the approximate solution equation (43) into equation (42) or equation (39) yields
i.e. the first term of equation (42) has the same order with 1λ2. Then the approximate solution expressed by equation (44) in this subsection is more accurate than the solution expressed by equation (33) in the previous subsection. However, the solution in the previous subsection is simpler. The corresponding cut-off frequency equation (21) is changed as (47)

sec.title: 3.3. Wave motions in a rod with polynomial or period profiles
sec.p: With the results in subsections 3.1 and 3.2, one can investigate the longitudinal wave motions with high frequency in non-uniform rods with arbitrary variable cross-sections. Here we present two examples. The first is a non-uniform rod with polynomial profiles assumed as (48)

Then the function q(x) is q(x)=n2(n2-1)α21(1+αx)2. And the wave number k(x) is a function of position x, which can be shown as equation (49) or (50) with the help of equations (33) or (44). (49a) (49b)
In terms of equation (47), if n > 2 or n < 0, the corresponding cut-off frequencies for positive traveling wave are (50) where L is the maximum value of x.
The second example is a non-uniform rod with period profiles. And the cross-section area of the rod is assumed as (51)
With the same procedure, the wave number could be shown as (52a) (52b)
The corresponding cut-off frequency is (53)

sec.title: 4. Longitudinal free vibrations of the non-uniform rods
sec.p: Some scholars have investigated longitudinal free vibrations of non-uniform rods (Anil and Sujith, 2005; Lau, 1984; Li, 2000). In this section, the longitudinal free vibrations of the non-uniform rods in section 2 are investigated. From the results in section 2, one can find a unified solution shown as equation (54).

where kj=ωj 2c0 2-d2Ai(x)/dx2Ai(x), Ai(x) are expressed by equations (12), (13), (16) and (18), ωj, c1, and c2 are determined by boundary conditions. c3 and c4 are determined by initial conditions. The classical boundary conditions are (55)
For Fixed-Fixed rod, substitution of equation (54) into the first equation of equation (55) yields
Then c1 = 1, c2 = 0 and its frequency equation read as (56)
For the Fixed-Free rod, c1 = 1, c2 = 0, and the corresponding frequency equation is (57)
For the Free-Free rod, c1 = 1, c2=2A0kjA′(0), and the corresponding frequency equation is (58)

sec.title: 5. Bending waves in a non-uniform Euler-Bernoulli beam
sec.p: Consider the wave guide shown in Figure 1 as a non-uniform Euler-Bernoulli beam undergoing bending motion. The transversal displacement for free vibrations is governed by (59)

The cross-section area A(x) and the second moment of area I(x) vary as (60) where c1 is a non-uniform parameter. A rectangle beam has constant thickness and its width varies as exponent variation. The material properties of the beam vary as (61)
Substitution of equation (61) and (60) into equation (59) gives (62) where c = c1 + c2 and α4=ρ0A0E0I0. Assume the positive going traveling solution of the bending wave as (63)
Substitution of it into equation (63) gives (64) (65)
Because k2 is positive, the solutions of equation (64) and (65) are obtained as (66, 67)
Substitution of equation (66) into equation (63) yields (68)
Using equation (67), the corresponding cut-off frequency could be obtained as (69)
Then, the corresponding phase velocity and group velocity are (70) and (71) respectively.
The corresponding kinetic energy is (72)

The strain energy could be obtained as (73) because
where M(x) is the moment of force at position x.

sec.title: 6. Conclusions
sec.p:
The positive wave motions in non-uniform rods and a class of beam are analyzed in this paper. The main results are listed as follows.
With constant wave velocity and no wave conversion, there is a class of non-uniform rods including four types of profiles with variation in geometry or material properties. Its traveling solutions and free vibration solutions are investigated. These results indicate that the kinetic energy of the wave motion is preserved as constant along the rod. And wave amplitude is inversely proportional to square root of the cross-section area A(x) of the non-uniform rod.
Other characters of the wave such as ω − K spectrogram, dispersion relation of phase velocity and group velocity, strain energy and cut-off frequency are also analyzed, tabulated and illustrated. If d2A(x)/dx2 is positive, the cut-off frequency ωc has a unified solution, i.e. equation (47).
For the non-uniform rods with arbitrary variable cross-sections and under the assumption of no wave conversion, whose longitudinal high frequency wave motions have similar results. However, its characters are the functions of position along the rods. Using the results, the wave characters in the non-uniform rods with exponent and polynomial profiles are studied.
The bending wave motion is investigated for one type of non-uniform Euler-Bernoulli beam with exponent variation in geometry and material properties. The bending strain energy is preserved as constant along the beam. The kinetic energy is preserved as constant with exponent variation in geometry and constant properties in material.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research was supported by the National Science Fund of China (No.11072157 and 50625518) and the Program for Changjiang Scholars and Innovative Research Team in University (IRT0971).

AnilRSujithRI (2005) Closed-form solutions for the free longitudinal vibration of inhomogeneous rods. Journal of Sound and Vibration 283(5): 1015–1030.
KumarBMSujthRI (1997) Exact solutions for the longitudinal vibration of non-uniformed rods. Journal of Sound and Vibration 207(5): 721–729.
LangleyRS (1999) Wave evolution, reﬂection, and transmission along inhomogeneous waveguides. Journal of Sound and Vibration 227(1): 131–158.
LauJH (1984) Vibration frequencies for a non-uniformed beam with end mass. Journal of Sound and Vibration 97(3): 513–521.
LeeSKMaceBRBrennanMJ (2007) Wave propagation, reﬂection and transmission in non-uniform one-dimensional waveguides. Journal of Sound and Vibration 304(1): 31–49.
LiQS (2000) Exact solutions for free longitudinal vibrations of non-uniform rods. Journal of Sound and Vibration 234(1): 1–19.
